#Text=Wikinews interviews former New Mexico governor Gary Johnson , presidential nominee of the Libertarian Party
#Text=Monday , November 5 , 2012

#Text=With the U.S. presidential election looming , former New Mexico governor and current Libertarian Party presidential nominee Gary Johnson spoke with Wikinews reporter William S. Saturn on an assortment of economic , foreign , and social issues .
#Text=In the interview , Johnson makes his final plea to voters before they cast their ballots on Election Day , November 6 .
#Text=Gary Johnson .
#Text=Image : Gary Johnson .
#Text=Though a member of the Libertarian Party in the early 1990s , Johnson was elected and re-elected governor of New Mexico in 1994 and 1998 as a Republican .
#Text=During his governorship , he vetoed over 750 bills , more than all other then-governors combined , and left the state with a $ 1 billion budget surplus .
#Text=He briefly ran for president as a Republican in 2011 before rejoining the Libertarian Party to seek its 2012 presidential nomination .

#Text=After winning the nomination this past May , Johnson has campaigned throughout the nation espousing the Fair Tax , spending cuts across the board , a repeal of Obamacare , an audit of the Federal Reserve , a non-interventionist foreign policy , an end to the Drug War , and legalization of same-sex marriage .
#Text=He and his running mate , Judge Jim Gray of California , have attained ballot access in all U.S. states except Michigan , where he is a write-in candidate , and Oklahoma .

#Text=Nationally , he has received four percent registered-voter support in the past two CNN/Opinion Research Polls that included him with President Barack Obama , Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney and Green Party nominee Jill Stein .
#Text=It is the campaign 's goal to reach five percent on Election Day , which will enable the party to receive ballot access and federal funding on par with the two major parties .
#Text=With Wikinews , Johnson discusses the federal budget , education , entitlements , the Syrian uprising , Mexican Drug War , same-sex marriage , the Libertarian Party , and his political future .
#Text=Economic matters
#Text=You say that as president , you would propose a balanced budget " not five or ten years down the road " but in 2013 .
#Text=Realistically can that budget pass , especially with a Congress hostile to your proposed spending cuts and tax plan ?

#Text=I would suggest that if I 'm elected president promising to submit a balanced budget to Congress in the year 2013 , and also promising to veto any legislation where expenses exceed revenue , even though they would override my veto , I 'm going to suggest to you that spending will be lower with those two promises kept than any other scenario you could possibly come up with .
#Text=You also propose decreasing federal education spending including decreases in Pell Grants and loans for college students .
#Text=Is that correct ?
#Text=Well the reason being is that because of guaranteed government student loans that is the reason why college tuition is so high .
#Text=It 's an artificial market .
#Text=It 's not a market made up of supply and demand .

#Text=And it 's a market where kids are going to school because they 're guaranteed a government student loan and because of that , the vast institutions of higher learning , colleges and universities are immune from pricing much much dramatically lower than they would have to price themselves at if government student loans did not exist .
#Text=And of course you would n't cut students off that are currently receiving student loans .
#Text=And that is n't to say that government student loans would go away .
#Text=It 's just that you would n't make government the guarantor of those student loans .
